figureCitation.captionText: Fig. 29. Laboulbenia spp. A. L. cristata Thaxt. Two mature thalli. – B–C. L. curtipes Thaxt. Mature thalli. Scale bars: 50 µm. Photographs from slides ZMUC C-F-122471 (A), ZMUC C-F-123641 (B–C).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences 28: 174 ( Thaxter 1893 )
. –

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type
: [Not designated] [Ind. loc.] “On elytra, abdomen, and legs of
Paederus littorarius Grav.
and
P. obliteratus Lec.
, Maine;
Paederus sp.
? Mexico and Nicaragua;
Paederus ruficollis Fabr.
, Austria”; FH .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Very common on
Paederus
(Col. Staphylinidae Paederinae ) and some closely related genera ( Megapaederus ? – this genus does not exist, it probably refers to
Megalopaederus Scheerpeltz, 1957
–,
Uncopaederus Korge, 1969
,
Madecapaederus Fagel, 1958
) from the five continents (
Santamaria et al. 1991
; Majewski 2008 ). Recently recorded from Thailand ( Rossi & Bernardi 2018 ), Cambodia , Romania (
Kong et al. 2020
), and Slovenia ( Rossi & Christian 2020 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 29.
Laboulbenia spp. A
.
L. cristata Thaxt. Two
mature thalli. – B–C .
L. curtipes Thaxt. Mature
thalli. Scale bars: 50 µm. Photographs from slides ZMUC C-F-122471 (A), ZMUC C-F-123641 (B–C).

subSubSection.paragraph:
First record from Denmark . It is probably one of the most common species of the genus
Laboulbenia
. Unmistakable species that does not seems to be related to any other. It does not present variations that deserve to be mentioned.
